Aspirants For Presidency
Propose Varied Platforms
Bill Morrill, Joe Jeziorski and Charlie Ginsberg have
submitted partial platforms on which they are running
for president of the Student Council by answering the
following 11 questions asked by the News-Letter.
1. What do you think is the most pressing problem the Student Council must face in the coming year?
Ginsberg: The main thing is not to plan new activities but to get our old problems done. There are several
projects this year which have not been run smoothly.
They should be done well by properly using responsibility

Senatorial Debate

Mayor, Long Stress
Military Flexibility
Editors Note: This is the fifth
installment in a series of answers by Democratic candidates
for the Senate, Dr. Clarence D.
Long of the economics department of Hopicins, and Mayor
Thomas D'Alesandro. This week
the rivals discuss the merits of
mobile armed forces versus pushbutton warfare and whether the
threat of hydrogen destruction is
a deterrent to all but limited or
local wars.
"I believe that our military
forces," stated Mayor D'Alesandro,"must be prepared to defend
Us in the event of any kind of
War, large or small. Increased
efforts on missiles should not be
at the expense of an effective
and mobile striking force."
that
Dr. Long suggested
America's entire armed forces
are organized on the "archaic
principle" that surface fights depend on separate communication.
He noted the incorrectness of this
principle by illustrating that the
Navy fights on land, sea and in
the air while the Army and Air

Honor

As a result of violations reported just before and during
the winter examination period, the Honor Commission
conducted seven trials in the
time from January 31 to
February 25, 1958. Ten students were accused in these
trials. They included four
juniors, one sophomore and
five freshmen; by schools,
there were eight Arts and
Sciences and two Engineers. In
eight instances the verdict
rendered was acquittal and in
two instances guilty. Two
students, one a junior and
one a freshman, were blacklisted and failed in the course
concerned.

Force both fight in the air and
on the ground.
Accepts Rockefeller Report
He accepted the Rockefeller
Report's recommendation that
the American armed forces be
organized on a task force basis
wherein one supreme commander would have unified command
over all facilities needed for the
completion of a mission.
The economics professor feels
that all Army generals and
naval admirals should be commissioned as generals in the
service of all the armed forces,
thereby eliminating parochialism
and particularism.
Furthermore, the chairman of
the joint chiefs of staff should
become the military adviser to
the President and the. Secretary
of State should become the Presidential supply and procurement
adviser. He believes that these
should be separate branches but
with liaison between them,
Stress Weapon Research
Urging additional stress on research and development in weaponry, Dr. Long said that the
United States should maintain
a flexible weapons system.
The complex weapons system
of modern warfare requires
fluidity, the professor believes.
America needs a better system
for the choice of weapons, because one wrong choice or the
dependance on a single weapon
"can put us past the point of no
return."

Vacation
School will resume on Monday, March 31, rather than
Tuesday, April 1, as erroniously announced in the BIACotillion Board calendar.

Salem Reports
Rescheduling
Of Walt Kelly
"Walt Kelly expressed his
deep regret at not being able
to appear for his talk, and asked
me to convey his regrets to the
students and let them know he
is anxious to speak here soon,"
said Student Council President
Tony Salem after a snowfall prevented the noted cartoonist from
appearing for his talk scheduled
last Friday in Shriver Hall.
The Shriver audience was
turned away when Salem announced that Kelly's flight from
New York "was cancelled and
he failed to catch a later plane."
He noted that the cartoonist
would be scheduled for a later
date, saying: "The Council regrets this but still hopes to have
him here for an illustrated talk."
After speaking to Kelly by
telephone, Salem reported that
the talk would be held "either
April 11 or 18." " The date will
be set as soon as possible," he
added.

The Cotillion Board, with the
unanimous approval of its members, has voted to cancel its
Spring Cotillion, May 10.
Cotillion Board President
Warren Wilhide reported that
the Board voted at a special
meeting last week to cancel the
dance, recently rescheduled by
the Student Council when the
IFB asked for a switch of dates
for its Spring Formal.
"The Board felt it should act
in keeping with its purpose of
helping other campus organizations have successful dances,
and in this case we didn't want
to infringe upon the D.S.R.C.,"
explained Wilhide. The D.S.R.C.
is holding a dance May 9.
"As far as I know there is now
no event planned for that Saturday night," said Wilhide, referring to the vacant May 10
date.
Wilhide also reported the election of three members of the
freshman class to the Cotillion
Board. They are: David Adams,
Thomas Galinski, and Richard
Popp.
"I think the Board made an
excellent choice, although selection was very difficult in naming three out of the twenty applicants," commented Wilhide.
Selection of the new members
was made last Saturday after
each applicant had been interviewed.
These three freshmen will not
become official members of the
Cotillion Board until he close
of the election meeting April 8.
"Official membership has been
delayed because the new members will not have had time to
become acquainted with the
senior members and workings of
the Board," said Wilhide,

and efficiency. Our aim is not
to make headlines. Our job is
to do a steady job and do it well.
If we start early with more
preparation, the work done this
year should bear fruit next year.

the Inter-Fraternity Board. I
would like to see the whole IFB

2. What are the other specific
problems the Student Council
must face?
Ginsberg: I have nothing
specific. I just think we can do
better the things that the Student Council is presently working on. It isn't specific; it's general. If the Council is efficient,
it will be respected. This will
overcome the problem of lack
of student interest.
Jeziorski: There should be
more activities for students like
Parents' Day and the trip to
Europe. It is up to the students
to initiate such plans and it is
the duty of the Council to encourage and supervise. Also, I
think that the Honor Commission should be better explained
to the freshmen during orientation. Too, we should encourage
students to come to their representatives with their gripes and
wishes.
Morrill: The assembly program should be expanded. Because the assembly committee of
the Council is too small and we
have insufficient funds, our
assembly program is poor. We
need a lot more work here. Also,

"It has been the feeling of

"Last year, at the time of a

stood trial. At the end of the
year the total was 25. Of these
20 were acquitted originally or
after appeal; 5 were found guilty
and received punishment.
"In the administration of this
year's Commission from May 20,
1957 to February 25, 1958, 17
trials have been conducted which
involved 21 accused parties, 7
of whom were found guilty.
Fitfy per cent of-the cases have

other fifty per cent by students.
In at least one case the student
committing the violation reported himself.
"Failure and blacklisting was
the penalty in six of the cases;
however, the Commission does
not operate on blind precedent,
and in the seventh case decided
on a penalty of blacklisting and
no credit in a single • examination. It was felt that such a
verdict • .. best met the responsibility of the Commission's to
promote the ideals of the Honor
System through enforcement.

body who nave erred and promotes the system both through

should allow the possibility that

member of the community .. .

result of many members' time

pamphlet in use for the past few

SymphonyMusical Success
But Crowd Disappointing
"Musically it was a success, but
I was disappointed in the crowd,"
said Hopkins Music Director
Osmar P. Steinwald this week
concerning Sunday's Baltimore
Symphony Orchestra Concert in
Shriver Hall.
"I was hoping for a better
Showing by the Hopkins community, especially since this was
the last in the 1958 concert
Series," commented Steinwald.
Renowned director Massimo
Freccia led the Baltimore Symphony in both of its last two
Shriver Concerts. Hugo Weisgal
led the Symphony in its opening
concert of the series.
"We spent a good deal of
money in procuring what we feel
was one of the best Symphony
Orchestras and certainly the best
directors available," said Steinwald, adding that "we also tried
to plan a diversified musical program which would appeal to the
Public. I don't know why the
response wasn't better."
"The Series was started last
Year in order to bring fine music
to Hopkins, especially to the students, who have few ready opPortunities to enlarge their cultural knowledge with good concerts. The new Shriver Hall auditorium affords an excellent place
for these concerts because it is

Campus Tours, Banquet
The Student Council and
Levering Hall YMCA are cosponsoring the annual Parents'
Day on April 26, according to Joe
Jeziorski, Chairman of the SC's
Parents' Day Committee.
Festivities will begin at 10 a.m.
when the parents and their sons
assemble at Levering Hall for
coffee. A tour of the campus will
follow, conducted by Omicron
Delta Kappa. After the tour the
parents will be addressed by Dr.
Clarence D. Long, professor of
economics and aspirant for the
Democratic Senatorial nomination.
In the afternoon, the parents
will be treated to a lacrosse game
between Hopkins and Loyola. A
special section will be reserved
in Homewood Field grandstand
for the parents.

for Parents' Day are $3.25. The
ticket admits the parents and

Oh, the awkwardness when the zero hour has flashed
by: heads have been set, copy has been proofread, and,
though the editorial navel has been thoroughly purged,
the inspiration has refused to take form. Maybe we're
disgusted?
Sure most of the campus politicians are knotheads;
assuredly certain men who petitioned for a class presidency should be ineligible for office because they have not
maintained a 'C' average; certainly the University should
partially subsidize the 'Y' Handbook, as it is an outrage
and a step below coercion to charge campus organizations
for what has, and should continue.to be, gratis publicity;
but yes fraternity presidents should sit on the Interfraternity Board; of course students who break legs on
University steps during southern snowfalls should have
insurance provided for them by the University; certainly
the topics of 'University Lectures' should be broadened
so that a sizable audience will be encouraged to attend.
But today we simply aren't in the mood to elaborate.

"Growth makes opportunities in
the telephone company"
In October, 1957, only four years after
graduation, Stanley W. Smith was appointed District Plant Engineer in Northwestern Bell Telephone Company. here
Stan tells what his responsibilities are
and how his promotion came about.
"I'm responsible for outside plant engineering in a district which includes
about one-third of all Bell telephones in
Nebraska outside of Omaha," Stan says.
"That's about 35,000 phones, and the
number is growing every day.
"The most important part of my job is
to plan for growth and have facilities
ready when needed. This means planning
for pole lines, aerial and underground
cable, and conduit lines to the central
office. I also make cost estimates for all

planned construction so that money can
be budgeted for it.
"This is the kind of job I really like—
one which combines engineering and
management. And it was the continuing
growth of the business," Stan points out,
"that opened up this new assignment for
me. My predecessor was appointed to a
newly created position and I was selected
to replace him.
"What the future holds for me depends
on a lot of things. But I can see from my
present job that growth will keep opening opportunities for myself and other
engineers like me. I'm more convinced
than ever that the telephone company is
the place to get ahead in an interesting
and challenging career."

Stan Smith graduated from the University of Nebraska in
1953 with a B.S. in E.E. degree. Ile is one of many young
men who are finding rewarding careers in the Bell Telephone
Companies. Find out about opportunities for you. Talk with
the Bell interviewer when he visits your campus, and read
the Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

MY CLOSEST SHAVE by

Bill Bridgeman

Douglas Test Pilot

"My closest shave was during the first try at a speed
record in the fantastic Douglas Skyrocket," says Test
Pilot Bill Bridgeman, author of The Lonely Sky. "A
special B-29 dropped me like a bomb at 30,000 feet ...
I turned on my rockets and climbed to 40,000 ...when
suddenly all power failed. Rocket power, cabin pressure, heat-everything went-and the window frosted
over so I couldn't see. Finally I got the radio going on an
emergency battery ... and a pilot in a chase
plane talked me down to a blind landing I"

The Johns Hopkins University television show "File 7" will
feature a program on lacrosse
this week over the ABC television
network.
The featured speaker will be
W. Kelso Morrill, mathematics
professor at Hopkins and former
coach of the Blue Jay lacrosse
team. He will be aided by the
current varsity coach, Bob Scott,
Wilson Fewster, assistant; and
the freshman coach, Fred Smith,
who will act as referee. Seventeen of the first string players

will also be on the show.
The program will describe the
history of the game and will explain the rules of present day
lacrosse. The equipment of the
players, the fundamentals of stick
handling, and the basic maneuvers of offense and defense will
also be described.
"File 7" will be seen in New
York and Chicago on Saturday
morning, March 22, direct from
Homewood Field. It will be filmed
for coast-to-coast presentation
on Sunday, March 30.

"Pleasing design is no accident," says 32-year-old TV
set designer Richard Montmeat. "It takes creative
planning. At General Electric, we're constantly developing new product designs — including some for
products which won't be on the market for several
years. Ever since joining General Electric, I've had
the opportunity and challenge of working toward the
designs of the future. As I see it, a company which
plans ahead gives me the chance to work out my own
future, too."
The creative accomplishments of Richard Montmeat have already brought him widespread recognition. He was awarded design patents in 1950 and
1955; he won the Industrial Designers Institute
Award in 1955; and his design for the 1958 General
Electric 17-inch portable television receiver was se-

lected for showing in an international design exposition in Milan, Italy.
Progress in pleasing design — making appliances
more enjoyable to own and use — is an important
factor in our nation's growing use of electricity and
in our constantly rising level of living. Planning now
to satisfy future customers is important not only to
the continued growth of the electrical ind4stry, but to
individual progress as well. Opportunity for longrange planning is part of the climate for self-development which is provided for General Electric's more
than 29,000 college-graduate employees.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAR. 21, 1958

NEWS -LETTER

Varsity Coach Cites
Balance Of Netters
By ED DENSON
"The varsity team has good
balance this year," said Coach
Carl Hartman of the Johns Hopkins tennis squad. "There are six
or seven boys on the squad capable of good tennis, but with the
Way the weather has been I
haven't been able to get a good
look at them. They haven't been
able to get any hard serves in
Yet, either," added Hartman.
Returnees from last year's
varsity and freshman teams include Don Squair, Captain of the
squad, who won half his matches
last year, Pete Hubbard, "number one on the frosh last year,
and should do well on the varsity," Nelson White, from last
Year's frosh team, Mike Garrick,

Bob Spielman, and Stuart Veiss,
all from last year's varsity, and
Carl Steeg, a senior who "hasn't
played since his freshman year,
but should play good tennis."
The first match will be against
Lafayette on April 2.
Coach Hartman and tennis
manager John Yang were high
in praise of Doug Brenner. "If
he had the time to practice, he
could play 'big time' tennis,"
said Hartman of the 6'2" lefthander. Another outstanding
prospect in Hartman's opinion is
John Urner.
Other top prospects for positions on the team include Richard Kozlowski, Mike Sher, Bob
Dickens, Pai Bericharit, Paul
Meyer, and Ted Kiesselbach.

Bill Schmeisser
Receives Honor
As Stick Great
"Father" Bill Schmeisser, a
former Johns Hopkins lacrosse
player and coach, will be honored posthumously during halftime ceremonies of the HopkinsRutgers lacrosse game on Saturday, March 29, by an award
for his having been elected to
the Lacrosse Hall of Fame.
Ross H. Smith, assistant director of athletics at Cornell and
president of the United States
Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, will present the award to
William C. Schmeisser, Jr., who
will accept for his father. Roy
Taylor and Laurie Cox were also
elected to the Lacrosse Hall of
Fame in the first election.
Schmeisser, known to the Hopkins lacrosse team as "Father
Bill," received his B.A. degree
from Johns Hopkins in 1902. He
coached the Blue Jay lacrosse
team for many years and was
with the Hopkins team which
represented the United States in
the Amsterdam Olympics. He
was also instrumental in the
organization of the Mt. Washington Club team.
In 1904, he wrote a book on
the coaching of lacrosse which
was the standard textbook for
coaches for fifty years.

Editors Note: This is the fifth
installment in a series of answers by Democratic candidates
for the Senate, Dr. Clarence D.
Long of the economics department of Hopicins, and Mayor
Thomas D'Alesandro. This week
the rivals discuss the merits of
mobile armed forces versus pushbutton warfare and whether the
threat of hydrogen destruction is
a deterrent to all but limited or
local wars.
"I believe that our military
forces," stated Mayor D'Alesandro,"must be prepared to defend
Us in the event of any kind of
War, large or small. Increased
efforts on missiles should not be
at the expense of an effective
and mobile striking force."

He accepted the Rockefeller
Report's recommendation that
the American armed forces be
organized on a task force basis
wherein one supreme commander would have unified command
over all facilities needed for the
completion of a mission.
The economics professor feels

service of all the armed forces,
thereby eliminating parochialism
and particularism.
Furthermore, the chairman of

adviser. He believes that these
should be separate branches but
with liaison between them,

United States should maintain
a flexible weapons system.
The complex weapons system
of modern warfare requires
fluidity, the professor believes.
America needs a better system
for the choice of weapons, because one wrong choice or the
dependance on a single weapon
"can put us past the point of no
return."

Salem Reports
Rescheduling
Of Walt Kelly
"Walt Kelly expressed his
deep regret at not being able
to appear for his talk, and asked
me to convey his regrets to the
students and let them know he
is anxious to speak here soon,"
said Student Council President
Tony Salem after a snowfall prevented the noted cartoonist from
appearing for his talk scheduled
last Friday in Shriver Hall.
The Shriver audience was
turned away when Salem announced that Kelly's flight from
New York "was cancelled and
he failed to catch a later plane."
He noted that the cartoonist
would be scheduled for a later
date, saying: "The Council regrets this but still hopes to have
him here for an illustrated talk."
After speaking to Kelly by
telephone, Salem reported that
the talk would be held "either
April 11 or 18." " The date will
be set as soon as possible," he
added.

The Cotillion Board, with the
unanimous approval of its members, has voted to cancel its
Spring Cotillion, May 10.
Cotillion Board President
Warren Wilhide reported that
the Board voted at a special
meeting last week to cancel the
dance, recently rescheduled by
the Student Council when the
IFB asked for a switch of dates
for its Spring Formal.
"The Board felt it should act
in keeping with its purpose of
helping other campus organizations have successful dances,
and in this case we didn't want
to infringe upon the D.S.R.C.,"
explained Wilhide. The D.S.R.C.
is holding a dance May 9.
"As far as I know there is now
no event planned for that Saturday night," said Wilhide, referring to the vacant May 10
date.
Wilhide also reported the election of three members of the
freshman class to the Cotillion
Board. They are: David Adams,
Thomas Galinski, and Richard
Popp.
"I think the Board made an
excellent choice, although selection was very difficult in naming three out of the twenty applicants," commented Wilhide.
Selection of the new members
was made last Saturday after
each applicant had been interviewed.
These three freshmen will not
become official members of the
Cotillion Board until he close
of the election meeting April 8.
"Official membership has been
delayed because the new members will not have had time to
become acquainted with the
senior members and workings of
the Board," said Wilhide,

SymphonyMusical Success
But Crowd Disappointing
"Musically it was a success, but
I was disappointed in the crowd,"
said Hopkins Music Director
Osmar P. Steinwald this week
concerning Sunday's Baltimore
Symphony Orchestra Concert in
Shriver Hall.
"I was hoping for a better
Showing by the Hopkins community, especially since this was
the last in the 1958 concert
Series," commented Steinwald.
Renowned director Massimo
Freccia led the Baltimore Symphony in both of its last two
Shriver Concerts. Hugo Weisgal
led the Symphony in its opening
concert of the series.
"We spent a good deal of
money in procuring what we feel
was one of the best Symphony
Orchestras and certainly the best
directors available," said Steinwald, adding that "we also tried
to plan a diversified musical program which would appeal to the
Public. I don't know why the
response wasn't better."
"The Series was started last
Year in order to bring fine music
to Hopkins, especially to the students, who have few ready opPortunities to enlarge their cultural knowledge with good concerts. The new Shriver Hall auditorium affords an excellent place
for these concerts because it is

Parents' Day To Feature
Campus Tours, Banquet
The Student Council and
Levering Hall YMCA are cosponsoring the annual Parents'
Day on April 26, according to Joe
Jeziorski, Chairman of the SC's
Parents' Day Committee.
Festivities will begin at 10 a.m.
when the parents and their sons
assemble at Levering Hall for
coffee. A tour of the campus will
follow, conducted by Omicron
Delta Kappa. After the tour the
parents will be addressed by Dr.
Clarence D. Long, professor of
economics and aspirant for the
Democratic Senatorial nomination.
In the afternoon, the parents
will be treated to a lacrosse game
between Hopkins and Loyola. A
special section will be reserved
in Homewood Field grandstand
for the parents.

fer as main speaker, will be provided in Levering Hall. Dr.
Thomas Hubbard will act as
master of ceremonies.
In the evening the parents
will be able to view the Barnstormers' production of "Charley's Aunt" in Shriver Hall.
Tickets Are $3.25
According to Jeziorski, tickets
for Parents' Day are $3.25. The
ticket admits the parents and
son to all of the activities.
Jeziorski asks that all of the
students "talk-up" this activity
in order to make it a "greater
success than ever before."

Poop-less
Oh, the awkwardness when the zero hour has flashed
by: heads have been set, copy has been proofread, and,
though the editorial navel has been thoroughly purged,
the inspiration has refused to take form. Maybe we're
disgusted?
Sure most of the campus politicians are knotheads;
assuredly certain men who petitioned for a class presidency should be ineligible for office because they have not
maintained a 'C' average; certainly the University should
partially subsidize the 'Y' Handbook, as it is an outrage
and a step below coercion to charge campus organizations
for what has, and should continue.to be, gratis publicity;
but yes fraternity presidents should sit on the Interfraternity Board; of course students who break legs on
University steps during southern snowfalls should have
insurance provided for them by the University; certainly
the topics of 'University Lectures' should be broadened
so that a sizable audience will be encouraged to attend.
But today we simply aren't in the mood to elaborate.

"Growth makes opportunities in
the telephone company"
In October, 1957, only four years after
graduation, Stanley W. Smith was appointed District Plant Engineer in Northwestern Bell Telephone Company. here
Stan tells what his responsibilities are
and how his promotion came about.
"I'm responsible for outside plant engineering in a district which includes
about one-third of all Bell telephones in
Nebraska outside of Omaha," Stan says.
"That's about 35,000 phones, and the
number is growing every day.
"The most important part of my job is
to plan for growth and have facilities
ready when needed. This means planning
for pole lines, aerial and underground
cable, and conduit lines to the central
office. I also make cost estimates for all

planned construction so that money can
be budgeted for it.
"This is the kind of job I really like—
one which combines engineering and
management. And it was the continuing
growth of the business," Stan points out,
"that opened up this new assignment for
me. My predecessor was appointed to a
newly created position and I was selected
to replace him.
"What the future holds for me depends
on a lot of things. But I can see from my
present job that growth will keep opening opportunities for myself and other
engineers like me. I'm more convinced
than ever that the telephone company is
the place to get ahead in an interesting
and challenging career."

Stan Smith graduated from the University of Nebraska in
1953 with a B.S. in E.E. degree. Ile is one of many young
men who are finding rewarding careers in the Bell Telephone
Companies. Find out about opportunities for you. Talk with
the Bell interviewer when he visits your campus, and read
the Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

MY CLOSEST SHAVE by

Bill Bridgeman

Douglas Test Pilot

"My closest shave was during the first try at a speed
record in the fantastic Douglas Skyrocket," says Test
Pilot Bill Bridgeman, author of The Lonely Sky. "A
special B-29 dropped me like a bomb at 30,000 feet ...
I turned on my rockets and climbed to 40,000 ...when
suddenly all power failed. Rocket power, cabin pressure, heat-everything went-and the window frosted
over so I couldn't see. Finally I got the radio going on an
emergency battery ... and a pilot in a chase
plane talked me down to a blind landing I"

The Johns Hopkins University television show "File 7" will
feature a program on lacrosse
this week over the ABC television
network.
The featured speaker will be
W. Kelso Morrill, mathematics
professor at Hopkins and former
coach of the Blue Jay lacrosse
team. He will be aided by the
current varsity coach, Bob Scott,
Wilson Fewster, assistant; and
the freshman coach, Fred Smith,
who will act as referee. Seventeen of the first string players

will also be on the show.
The program will describe the
history of the game and will explain the rules of present day
lacrosse. The equipment of the
players, the fundamentals of stick
handling, and the basic maneuvers of offense and defense will
also be described.
"File 7" will be seen in New
York and Chicago on Saturday
morning, March 22, direct from
Homewood Field. It will be filmed
for coast-to-coast presentation
on Sunday, March 30.

"Pleasing design is no accident," says 32-year-old TV
set designer Richard Montmeat. "It takes creative
planning. At General Electric, we're constantly developing new product designs — including some for
products which won't be on the market for several
years. Ever since joining General Electric, I've had
the opportunity and challenge of working toward the
designs of the future. As I see it, a company which
plans ahead gives me the chance to work out my own
future, too."
The creative accomplishments of Richard Montmeat have already brought him widespread recognition. He was awarded design patents in 1950 and
1955; he won the Industrial Designers Institute
Award in 1955; and his design for the 1958 General
Electric 17-inch portable television receiver was se-

lected for showing in an international design exposition in Milan, Italy.
Progress in pleasing design — making appliances
more enjoyable to own and use — is an important
factor in our nation's growing use of electricity and
in our constantly rising level of living. Planning now
to satisfy future customers is important not only to
the continued growth of the electrical ind4stry, but to
individual progress as well. Opportunity for longrange planning is part of the climate for self-development which is provided for General Electric's more
than 29,000 college-graduate employees.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAR. 21, 1958

NEWS -LETTER

Varsity Coach Cites
Balance Of Netters
By ED DENSON
"The varsity team has good
balance this year," said Coach
Carl Hartman of the Johns Hopkins tennis squad. "There are six
or seven boys on the squad capable of good tennis, but with the
Way the weather has been I
haven't been able to get a good
look at them. They haven't been
able to get any hard serves in
Yet, either," added Hartman.
Returnees from last year's
varsity and freshman teams include Don Squair, Captain of the
squad, who won half his matches
last year, Pete Hubbard, "number one on the frosh last year,
and should do well on the varsity," Nelson White, from last
Year's frosh team, Mike Garrick,

Bob Spielman, and Stuart Veiss,
all from last year's varsity, and
Carl Steeg, a senior who "hasn't
played since his freshman year,
but should play good tennis."
The first match will be against
Lafayette on April 2.
Coach Hartman and tennis
manager John Yang were high
in praise of Doug Brenner. "If
he had the time to practice, he
could play 'big time' tennis,"
said Hartman of the 6'2" lefthander. Another outstanding
prospect in Hartman's opinion is
John Urner.
Other top prospects for positions on the team include Richard Kozlowski, Mike Sher, Bob
Dickens, Pai Bericharit, Paul
Meyer, and Ted Kiesselbach.

Bill Schmeisser
Receives Honor
As Stick Great
"Father" Bill Schmeisser, a
former Johns Hopkins lacrosse
player and coach, will be honored posthumously during halftime ceremonies of the HopkinsRutgers lacrosse game on Saturday, March 29, by an award
for his having been elected to
the Lacrosse Hall of Fame.
Ross H. Smith, assistant director of athletics at Cornell and
president of the United States
Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, will present the award to
William C. Schmeisser, Jr., who
will accept for his father. Roy
Taylor and Laurie Cox were also
elected to the Lacrosse Hall of
Fame in the first election.
Schmeisser, known to the Hopkins lacrosse team as "Father
Bill," received his B.A. degree
from Johns Hopkins in 1902. He
coached the Blue Jay lacrosse
team for many years and was
with the Hopkins team which
represented the United States in
the Amsterdam Olympics. He
was also instrumental in the
organization of the Mt. Washington Club team.
In 1904, he wrote a book on
the coaching of lacrosse which
was the standard textbook for
coaches for fifty years.

6. Did the Council's committees
work well this year and if not,
is there any remedy?
Ginsberg: The ability of the
committees to do work depends
on the committee and its members. They can work well if the
president is responsible and
keeps them going.
Jeziorski: Yes.
Morrill: No. the committees
didn't work too well this year.
Time was wasted arguing on the
floor of Council meetings about
issues which should have been
decided in committee. The only
remedy is getting a president
and vice-president who will get
on the committees and see that
they get their work done.
7. What do you think of the
recent parking amendments? Do
you have any alternative plan?
Ginsberg: Parking is a problem which must be solved. I believe the recent amendments will
cause resentment. Something
about the exclusion of dormitory
student parking is unfair, but I
have no suggestions for an alternative plan.
Jeziorski: I have no other plan
because although I would like to
see more parking on campus and
though I would be hurt by one
of the Amendments, there seems
to be no other feasible plan at
the present. This I believe because parking lots or garages
are too expensive for the school
to build and there are influential people who believe that any
additional parking space would
destroy the natural beauty of
the campus. Extra parking on
neighboring streets would not
solve the problem.
